posts.com:
/r9k/ is an imageboard where there are no exact reposts.

1. If you attempt to post something unoriginal, it is not posted, and you are muted temporarily.
2. The time with which you are muted for doubles with each transgression.
3. Each mute time is 2^n in seconds where n is the number of times you have transgressed. So, your mute time doubles each time you fuck up.
4. Backlinks, eg >>1, are not viewed by the robot. So "lolwut" and ">>2 lolwut" are the same post, in the eyes of the robot.
5. Gibberish at the end of a post to force originality may result in mod intervention (no BLOX posts please).
6. Images are NOT included in the filter, only text.
7. Your mute count slowly decreases over time.
8. You cannot post a picture without text.
9. Unicode is blocked. Sorry, too many exploits (Cyrillic letters, etc).
10. Posts require a certain minimum amount of original content in order to be posted.
11. Post sane, real content, well thought out replies, and mutes are unlikely.
12. The original algorithm was designed by XKCD:
http://blag.xkcd.com/2008/01/14/robot9000-and-xkcd-signal-attacking-noise-in-chat/

A video cropped up on my suggested list, so I clicked on it out of interest. The video was of an English man filming an industrial estate (couldn't work out why) and then being asked to stop filming by employees of one of the companies. The man filming seemed to relish the confrontation and would not explain why he was filming them or their work building. He was sarcastic and pompous with the employees who were pretty nonplussed, as I was I, watching this scene unfold. It was bizarre, and seemed like the man filming was getting a kick out of harassing people.

I've looked a bit deeper and there are multiple videos of this phenomenon, from different YouTubers, with a decent amount of commentators and viewers who seemingly support this activity. Some of them antagonising police officers and so on. I can't work out what the deal is with these people; is it simply to harass the working population? For attention? To make a political point? Or what?

Has anyone had any experience with these strange fellows? And if so, could you work out what the motive is? I'd be interested to know about this crankish behaviour.

30's aren't old (and certainly not "old fuck"), but neither young as in being a teen or a young adult It's adulthood, simple as that. I'd consider someone old when they turn 40, but not 30. I often think people who project these ideas that any life stage beyond your early twenties being worthless, are either teens that don't have a lot of life experience and make massive judgements over what little notion they have about growing up, or adults in that age that romanticize their teens and twenties because it was a happier time in their lives (whether they miss the free time, the energy, or experiencing certain things for the first time). Society as a whole also romanticizes teens and young adults as the only good time you'll ever have in your life, so I understand why many people share the belief that anything beyond 25 is garbage.

Anyways, I skimmed through the conversation and I only saw people pretty much projecting their frustrations about being "old fucks" and not having their life together, so I believe that's the root of the problem here. I hear a lot about "yeah people think if you don't do X and Y things by the time you're 30 it means there's something wrong with you!". For those anons, I only want to say one thing: succumbing to peer pressure will make everyone everyone happy... except yourself. Yeah, people will always demand you do things in order to satisfy ages-old societal expectations (that may be even harder to fulfill as time goes by), but your own happiness should be what ultimately matters. You can't make everyone happy, because everyone has different ideas of what it means to have your life together. The only goals that matter are the ones you set for yourself!

Time for a small 2000-character limit-constrained rant, then.
I'd be more comfortable talking about intuition in general. Explaining "Ni" while completely avoiding going into "Ne" territory and vice versa feels quite futile, silly and wrong. Without written materials, it's much easier to explain their difference as merely a type of utilization of the same processes.

One of the reasons why I got interested in Jung is his musings on archetypes make quite a lot of sense if brought from unconscious to conscious and viewed through the scope of flows of clusters of basic patterns, with such swarms containing different characteristics of their own, including the way they can be manifested into a form through which their characteristics can be analyzed, what forms they can be manifested into, what characteristics and categorizations can be applied, et cetera.
It's like the polar opposite of "Sacred Geometry." And you need to grasp the basics for both polarities to understand how metaphorical magnets work.

Intuition works with clusters within the unconscious on basis of the personal and ancestral libraries existing within the essence of the swarm-like mortal coil (which, in its turn, also receives inputs from libraries of the external world).
Libraries of memory and libraries of material world can be put in the category of libraries born as the result of pursuing the results of idealization.*
Epiphany, with his shadow brother Apophenia getting in his way. Intuition does not play just a solo role in those, as they, by definition, have a conscious aspect to them (being a result of a convergence of at least some of the actual cognitive functions). Yet, the importance of its role cannot be overstated.

And so, what is it for?
Epiphany is one of the few bringing the new keys allowing the conscious libraries to progress towards the path of the *ideal of Akashic Records.

I'm confident I will be able to provide more additions to this answer as I will learn further.

Novel Cognitive Functions Arise at the Convergence of Macroscale Gradients
>In this review, we synthesize emerging evidence that a variety of novel functions in the higher-order brain regions are due to convergence. Convergence of macroscale gradients brings feature-rich representations into close proximity, presenting an opportunity for novel functions to arise.
>we demonstrate that convergent areas have three properties, they: (1) are at the peak of the processing hierarchy, (2) combine the most abstracted representations, and (3) are equidistant from other convergent areas. As information moves from primary sensory cortices to higher-order brain regions, it becomes abstracted and hierarchical. Eventually, these processing gradients converge at a point equally and maximally distant from their sensory origins. This convergence, which produces multifaceted cognitive functions, such as mentalizing another person's thoughts or projecting into a future space, parallels evolutionary and developmental characteristics of such regions, resulting in new cognitive and affective faculties.

I am assuming you're interested in talking about this beyond just expressing your personal beliefs.
>Personality is black magic that causes arrested development in its practitioners. The truth is Anatta - no self
Self is not personality. I agree that trying to outsource "Self" to "Personality" (or to anything that is not "Self" itself) is foolish, however. Dukkha isn't "Self" either. "Understanding of Self" isn't "Self" as well, to that matter.
>"it's not that we don't believe the self is a real thing, it's just you all believe the self is really real"
If the Self assumes it exists, it exists.
If the Self assumes it doesn't exist, it still exists to assume that it doesn't exist.
>The truth is Anatta - no self
And so, who made your post?

>There is what we may think of as a Buddhist answer to the triad being, consciousness, bliss. It is the triad referred to as "the three hallmarks" (P: ti-lakkhana), that is, the hallmarks of phenomenal existence. These are impermanence, unsatisfactoriness, absence of self. The order betrays the Upanisadic reasoning. Things are impermanent, i.e., ever-changing, and by that token they are not satisfactory, and by that token they cannot be the atman.
>The third hallmark is very often mistranslated (sometimes by me too, in the past) as "not having a self or essence". That is indeed how later Buddhists came to interpret it, but that was not its original meaning - in fact, it is doubly misleading. Both Pali grammar 14 and a comparison with the Vedanta show that the word means "is not atman" rather than "does not have atman". Comparison with the Vedanta further shows that the translation "self" is appropriate, as the reference is to living beings. However, as time went by the term was taken as a possessive compound and also taken to refer to everything, so that it became the one-word expression of the Buddha's anti-essentialism.
https://archive.org/details/WhatTheBuddhaThought/page/n85/mode

>>71791088
I don't agree that intuition has more unconscious parts than any other function does. It's just new and difficult to make conscious. And it's difficult because it's hard to explain to the self, and that's because it's the furthest removed from the tangible. It's the opposite of Se, which is probably the most archaic and easiest function. I know Jung said intuition was largely unconscious, but that's because the culture of the time he was in. "I don't know how I know, I just know" was much more acceptable for people in his time than today. In this era of political obnoxiousness, laypeople have to be their own lawyers, for better or worse.
Fortunately, if we work at it, intuition can be a largely conscious process. Today we minimize the unconscious parts to what is strictly necessary. That pesky fundamental theorem of psychology that no one wants to declare plainly will always apply. That every conscious event has an equivalent, unconscious backlash. That has a conscious reaction. And then an unconscious one. And so on like waves.

>>71802743
>But if you're prepared for that why'd you quit medicine?
I was on my third year. As I said before, my country went into a pretty bad humanitarian crisis, and my med school went into financial crisis as well. Sometimes I'd spend like a month without classes because teachers were broke as hell. Months before I quit, most of the classrooms were closed because of poor maintenance, the labs were closed as well. People would get robbed in the middle of class (luckily it never happened to me). The country was also going through famine and a deep financial crisis, so it was becoming harder and harder to do basic things like transportation or affording food every day.

That, plus coming home to my parents telling me to kill myself or my mom saying she should kill me herself, made me take the decision to leave the country and go live abroad. It took me years to become financially stable on my own, but last year I began to earn enough to afford a degree.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>71803405
I (would've) graduated in '97. Pic related is my my graduating class from my high school yearbook (I'm not in it). In retrospect, it was extremely white, but no one thought much of it back then. During my time there I only remember a handful of black kids, maybe 4-5 east Indian and Pakistani kids. Unfortunately most of the black kids were the acting-out, future criminal types, but the ones who weren't seemed to get along well, and were treated just like anyone else. The area was/is pretty liberal and people were pretty chill and accepting in general.
Life was pretty good, honestly, though I myself was depressed and struggling in school. But in general, pretty good. Nobody worried about school shooters back then. No one had cellphones obviously. No social media. Internet was barely a thing. I'd go over to friends' houses after school and we'd play basketball or computer/video games, or hang out and watch 90s cartoons like Animaniacs.
Most kids dressed pretty 90s normcore, but grunge/alternative music and fashion definitely had some influence too, as did skater fashion. There were definitely a few cute alternative girls who dressed in thriftstore clothes that I had crushes on. Gangsta rap was also popular around '94-'95, which had some influence on fashion and attitude, but it was a small minority and mostly white kids aping what they saw on MTV.
I miss it, when I think about it. I may have been miserable a lot of the time, but nothing in the 25 years since has afforded the same opportunity for socializing and making friends as high school. I've been alone for so many years now. It's true what they say - you really don't know how good you have it until it's gone.

Not at all. Not in California, not in a major city. My high school did serve one of the wealthier neighborhoods in town, but none of my friends lived there and all were from solidly middle class homes. They just happened to be resonably intelligent, well-adjusted and personable people with nothing major holding them back. Of my immediate friend group in high school, two went to work for a major tech company as programmers after graduating college. One of those later cofounded, and still works at, a bay area startup. Another got his PhD and now does government research. Another is a data analyst for a large healthcare provider. All of the aforementioned are married and have at least one child. I do have one friend who has worked well-paying tech jobs, but is currently not employed and living off savings, playing PC games hours a day and slumming it in a bachelor pad with a rooommate. But that's no better than what I"m doing with my life at the moment, so I can't judge. And he seems to being enjoying himself at least.
Granted, my friend group seem to be outliers; other people I didn't know so well that I've looked up aren't typically in those high end professions, But by and large they look like they're doing well enough and have happy families.

The setting is a weird mix of DBZ shit, aliens, giant robots, superhero stuff.

Gaia's mother was killed by an Ana, a sort of overarching main villain type in the series, and her father left her on Earth where she was born with his old friend to raise her while he sought out her mothers killer.

Growing up Gaia was already strong enough to lift a truck over her head at 7 or 8 years old, by her mid teens she could fly and access her connection to the Ether, a primordial magical chi/ki like energy that surrounded everything in the universe and even allows some to breath it in the void of space.

By 20 years old and years after graduating high school she's restless, spending her type tooling around town, working at a grocery store, playing music with her friends and secretly helping people and thwarting criminals around the various towns in Wyoming.

This is around where the story picks up with Gaia going out into the world traveling to a big city on the west coast where she makes friends, fights crime, yada yada. The main plot of the first story involves her meeting another Ana sent by her mothers killer to Earth for plot and McGuffin reasons, shit gets real, it gets very Dragon Ball Z.

That's the basic gist of the first story.

>>71801157
>I do have doubts that anybody outside of that will, though
It's hard to find a point where you can confidently say "I understand your life, I know your life, I had the same experience in my life", without lying a little bit. At the same time, you must be... historical, if you want to have nothing about your life story that someone else can relate to. I'm not autistic, I think at least, but I used to ravenously hate when people simply were pushed upwards while there's nothing behind their image. I focused on criticizing so much in my life that one of my best skills became making up creative insults and hard hitting personal attacks. I'm a /b/ native. I treated everyone in my life who built me up as replacable, and I never really cared for other people's misery or death, I always thought "as long as I can survive, it will be fine in the end".
I'm young, but I've lived many years still. After I realized I maybe fell a little bit in love, massively, with Earth chan, it felt like slowly scraping off years of slime off an old carpet, working through layers of isolating my heart to say things like "I don't need to care if they die" to myself, or things like "that asshole can't just get away with being considered the smartest when they get such a simple problem wrong":
I still think similar things sometimes, and I know that there was something justful and valuable somewhere within these thoughts, but since I realized what the rest of the World has done for me, it becomes impossible to just hate them for what they are. I think it's very possible to be critical, and goofy, to be stern and stand up to opression, and still be gentle and kind to others.
Why wouldn't you call them friends? If anything, I was the one who wasn't a friend. To clarify, I treated them wrong, they treated me well. I've been able to depend on them, and my life and career only exist because they never gave me up. Looking back, I feel guilty for never realizing this.
